item.title: 8 Best Martial Arts Pokemon, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Throh, inspired by Judo, is a brave warrior, mastering its craft in throwing bigger foes despite some stats disadvantages.
  • Sawk, resembling a karate expert, is marginally stronger than Throh, with faster and stronger attacks, such as powerful karate chops.
  • Hitmonlee is the strongest martial artist with diamond-hard kicks, outranking his brethren, Hitmonchan and Hitmontop, in speed and power.

Many of the thousands of Pokemon that make up the Pokemon world are based on real-life objects, animals, and themes. For example, Pokemon has a long lineup of beasts resembling monkeys, such as Chimchar and Mankey.

One such real-life resemblance is martial artists, with several Pokemon in the fighting type class of Pokemon resembling combatants of various disciplines. While most of these are normal variants of Pokemon, some of them are, in fact, legendaries. Thus, some martial artist-based Pokemon are stronger than others in their skill and ability when battling. Despite this, most are brave warriors and second to none in their ability to fight.

8 Throh

Master Of Powerful Throws

HP

120

Attack

100

Defense

85

Special Attack

30

Special Defense

85

Speed

45

The least powerful martial arts-inspired Pokemon on this list, Throh is neither void of ability nor weak. Often picking on opponents bigger than itself, Throh travel in packs looking to throw enemies far greater than themselves. Fearless and a staunch warrior inspired by the Japanese fighting style of Judo, Throh is a master of its craft, coming in slightly below Sawk due to certain disadvantageous stats.

7 Sawk

Unyielding, Powerful Karate Chop

HP

75

Attack

125

Defense

75

Special Attack

30

Special Defense

75

Speed

85

The Karate Pokemon Sawk is known for its exceptionally powerful karate chops, training without sleep to become an expert in its craft. Often found in mountainous regions, these Pokemon train to build immense strength without respite.

Its design is based on a karate warrior donning a robe and a black belt in battle. Upon tying its belt, its moves get stronger when conditioning and in conflict. Sawk is marginally stronger than Throh, with better abilities, faster attacks, and more powerful attacks than its Gen 5 counterpart.

6 Hitmontop

Balanced, Defensive Martial Artist

HP

50

Attack

95

Defense

95

Special Attack

35

Special Defense

110

Speed

70

Introduced after the other two Hitmon brothers, Hitmontop spins on its head to deliver rapid kicks that, despite its velocity, are weaker than its sibling's moves, with slower speed and power, making it more fragile. Nevertheless, it has the highest defense out of the three, making it a rather tanky addition for a martial arts-inspired team.

5 Hitmonchan

Powerful, Defensive Punching Specialist

HP

50

Attack

105

Defense

79

Special Attack

35

Special Defense

110

Speed

76

Otherwise known as the punching Pokemon, Hitmonchan is a Generation 1 Pocket Monster introduced in the original Pokemon Red and Blue games. Resembling an elite boxer, the Pokemon is known for throwing intense flurries of punches that can break even solid concrete.

While this Pokemon has an impressive defense, it is generally considered weaker than Hitmonlee but comes in stronger than Hitmontop in terms of stats.

4 Hitmonlee

Elite, Powerful Kicking Specialist

HP

50

Attack

120

Defense

53

Special Attack

35

Special Defense

110

Speed

87

The strongest of the Hitmon trio, Hitmonlee, or the kicking Pokemon, is a master of using kicks in martial arts due to its elasticated legs that can stretch to smack an opponent from a distance with devasting power. Hitmonlee's foot is known to go as hard as a diamond when kicking, making an opponent on the receiving end wish they never engaged with the elite fighter.

Hitmonlee stands stronger than its Hitmon brethren, with higher health, speed, and attack.

3 Mienshao

Swift, Whip-Like Kung Fu Master

HP

65

Attack

125

Defense

60

Special Attack

95

Special Defense

60

Speed

105

The third-strongest Pokemon here is Mienshao. Introduced in the Pokemon Black and White games, Mienshao uses its fur like a whip to attack opponents at extreme speed. The Pokemon was inspired by whip-fighting and a Chinese variation of kung fu known as Shaolin, with the pocket monster's stance resembling a kung fu fighter.

Mienshao is stronger than Hitmonlee, with a higher overall stat ratio and superiority across most stats apart from special defense.

2 Kubfu

Legendary Martial Arts Trainee

HP

60

Attack

90

Defense

60

Special Attack

53

Special Defense

50

Speed

72

The pre-evolved form of Urshifu, Kubfu was introduced in Pokemon Sword and Shields Ilse of Armour DLC, acting as a central part of the expansion. Players must befriend Kubfu, train it, and bond with the pocket monster before it can evolve into the powerful Urshifu.

While small in stature, Kubfu is no pushover as a warrior, being a legendary Pokemon of powerful proportions. Nevertheless, Kubfu is weaker than its evolved form, Urshifu, but it is far more powerful than the other Pokemon mentioned previously.

1 Urshifu

Unstoppable Master Of Martial Arts

HP

100

Attack

130

Defense

100

Special Attack

63

Special Defense

60

Speed

97

Urshifu is the strongest martial arts Pokemon here. An evolved form of the legendary Pokemon Kubfu, Urshifu is central to the Pokemon Sword and Shield DLC, Ilse of Armour . Urshifu can take two forms: single strike and rapid strike style, differing in typing and moves learned, such as rapid strike as well as Urshifu's ability to use water moves due to its water typing.

Urshifu's name means wushu, a Chinese martial arts term. Packing a real punch in battle, it can gigantamax and use signature moves such as G-Max One Blow and G-Max Rapid Flow to squash opponents under its might.

item.title: Disney Dreamlight Valley: How to Make Green Bean Casserole
item.description:
Disney Dreamlight Valley 's The Storybook Vale DLC introduces even more meals to the game's ever-expanding recipe collection. One such Storybook Vale recipe is Green Bean Casserole, a hearty and healthy-looking dish peppered with golden-colored beans. Interestingly, the in-game description for Green Bean Casserole also playfully warns players not to make the meal using magic beans to avoid possible beanstalk disasters. While it won't whip up any magic beanstalks, you might want to know how to make Green Bean Casserole in Disney Dreamlight Valley and what ingredients you need.

In addition, learning how to make Green Bean Casserole has its uses as a pretty simple 3-star Disney Dreamlight Valley entrée recipe that requires just three ingredients that aren't too tricky to get hold of.

How To Make Green Bean Casserole in Disney Dreamlight Valley

To make Green Bean Casserole in Disney Dreamlight Valley , you need The Storybook Valley expansion plus the below ingredients:

  • Green Beans
  • Onion
  • Porcini Mushroom

You only need to add one of each ingredient above to the cooking pot. Once cooked, you can eat Green Bean Casserole to replenish +652 energy or sell it at Goofy's Stall for 607 Gold Star Coins . You might also want to make Casserole if you're ticking off some 3-star meal duties or if it pops up as a favorite gift for villagers. Alternatively, you might want to cook it to add the dish to your Disney Dreamlight Valley recipe collection.

Where To Find Green Bean Casserole Ingredients in Disney Dreamlight Valley

You can find all the necessary ingredients to make Green Bean Casserole in Disney Dreamlight Valley as outlined below:

Green Beans

As you might expect, the star of the show when making Green Bean Casserole is green beans . To get green beans in Disney Dreamlight Valley , you can buy green bean seeds from Goofy's Stall in the Wild Woods in The Storybook Vale's Everafter biome.

A bag of green seeds costs 250 Gold Star Coins , which is pretty pricey for seeds. Green beans also take a lengthy four hours to grow, and you get just one per harvest. Therefore, it's best to stock up on and plant plenty of seeds if you've got the spare coins. It's probably not worth eating green beans, as they only top up +59 energy when consumed. However, you can also sell them for 209 Gold Star Coins each.

Porcini Mushroom

You can find Porcini Mushrooms growing in all areas of The Storybook Vale's Everafter biome, which covers:

  • The Wild Woods
  • Teapot Falls
  • The Fallen Fortress
  • The Beanstalk Marshes

The Wild Woods is the first area in Everafter you can unlock and has a few Porcini Mushroom nodes dotted about. Additionally, you can eat Porcini Mushroom to restore +130 energy or sell them at Goofy's Stall for 55 Gold Star Coins each.

Onion

Lastly, you must add one onion to the cooking pot when making Green Bean Casserole. To get onions in Disney Dreamlight Valley , you can grab them from Goofy's Stall in the Forest of Valor. You can purchase a bag of onion seeds for a reasonable 50 Gold Star Coins or, when available, fully-grown onions for a costly 255 Gold Star Coins . You now have everything you need to cook a nourishing bowl of Green Bean Casserole.

item.description: Exfil is a tactical round-based FPS game from Misultin Studios that is available now in early access. Watch the official trailer here.

item.title: How Indiana Jones and the Great Circle Nails Its Cinematic Combat
item.description:
Summary

  • Players can choose their combat approach in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle, reflecting Indy's style.
  • Sound effects in combat, like Indy's punches and whip crack, enhance the cinematic feel of the game.
  • Emphasizing Indy's vulnerability and resourcefulness, combat in the game mirrors the films' authentic action.

MachineGames was aiming for a truly authentic Indiana Jones experience with Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , and it turns out that players got that very thing. While much of this authenticity is summed up in the developer's efforts to make Indiana Jones and the Great Circle 's version of Indy as true to the original as possible, the game's authenticity still flows all the way down to its effective reflection of the combat often seen in an Indiana Jones film. Indiana Jones doesn't always engage in combat with his foes, nor does he prefer to, but there are plenty of times when combat is not only warranted, it's necessary for Indy to move on to the next step of his adventure.

In Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , players can spend as much or as little time in direct combat as they wish — it all boils down to whether they prioritize exploration, attempt a stealthy approach to subduing enemies, or simply run in guns blazing. Nevertheless, any time players do spend in direct combat in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is enhanced by its ability to reflect the cinematic feel that only an Indiana Jones movie might have otherwise accomplished. Whether it's the sound of every punch landing on an enemy's face or Indiana Jones' quick-thinking in the midst of chaos, Indiana Jones and the Great Circle nails its cinematic combat in one way or another.

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle's Combat Nails That Cinematic Feel

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle's Combat Is Driven by Sound

One of the most recognizable elements of Indiana Jones and the Great Circle 's combat is its sound — particularly, the sound of a punch. Sound effects for punches have varied across films for countless decades, but they have arguably become more realistic in the modern age. Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , however, chose to exchange modern sound effects for nostalgia when it comes to the sound of Indy's punches in the game. Rather than going for a more realistic sounding punch, Indiana Jones and the Great Circle 's punch sound effect is almost a perfect replica of the same sound effect used for Indy's punches in the movies.

Any time players do spend in direct combat in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is enhanced by its ability to reflect the cinematic feel that only an Indiana Jones movie might have otherwise accomplished.

The crack of Indy's whip is another element of Indiana Jones and the Great Circle that gives its combat that cinematic feel. In fact, it's clear that MachineGames spent just about as much time developing Indiana Jones and the Great Circle 's whip as it did anything else in the game, as it looks, feels, and sounds exactly how it does in the movies. While the whip can be used outside of combat in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , hearing the loud pop at the end of a whip-swing in combat makes it feel all the more true-to-film.

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle Makes It Easy to Get Overwhelmed

Another element of Indiana Jones ' combat that Indiana Jones and the Great Circle needed to get right for authenticity's sake is the fact that Indiana Jones is not a superhero and therefore often finds himself facing overwhelming odds. There are moments throughout the Indiana Jones movies where something will go wrong or Indy will make a mistake, only for him to quickly find himself outnumbered and outmatched. These moments also happen in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , where the behavior and responses of enemies are often unpredictable, sometimes forcing players to improvise their way out of danger or to simply run away as fast as they possibly can.

By balancing the chaotic unpredictability of a brawl with Indy's resourcefulness, Indiana Jones and the Great Circle ensures that every fight in the game is a cinematic moment that feels pulled straight from the films. MachineGames' dedication to authenticity in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , from the nostalgic punch sound effects to the whip's signature crack, shines through in every encounter, immersing players in the kind of action that has always defined Indiana Jones . With its attention to detail and commitment to honoring the franchise's legacy, Indiana Jones and the Great Circle shows what it truly means to step into the boots of one of cinema's most iconic adventurers.

item.title: All Overwatch 2 x Avatar: The Last Airbender Hero Skins
item.description:
As part of the seasonal updates and live-service format, Overwatch 2 tends to rotate a variety of different aspects of the game, such as limited-time game modes, in-game events, challenge opportunities, rewards, Battle Pass themes, and more. One of the ways in which they introduce new cosmetics for some of everyone's favorite heroes is through the more recent crossover collaboration events, which began a few Competitive seasons into Overwatch 2 and have continued to appear on a seasonal rotation moving forward.

These crossover collaboration events feature a limited-time opportunity to claim special cosmetics, weapon charms, profile decorations, voice lines, and more featuring Overwatch heroes/villains and their take on cosplaying certain characters from various games, anime, and other pop culture names and franchises. Previously, these events have included the likes of One Punch Man , K-pop group LE SSERAFIM , Cowboy Bebop, Transformers , and more. With Overwatch 2's Season 14 arriving in December 2024, a new crossover event is set to go live at some point, featuring Avatar: The Last Airbender . Everything you need to know about this collaboration event and all featured characters who are receiving new skins has been included in the guide below.

All Overwatch 2 + Avatar: The Last Airbender Crossover Collab Skins

In Overwatch 2, the Avatar: The Last Airbender crossover collaboration event is set to go live on December 17, 2024 . This event, like many others, will bring a series of hero skins featuring certain Overwatch characters dressed up as characters from the ATLA show, as well as some event challenges that can be completed for additional Battle Pass XP and rewards. Every Avatar: The Last Airbender + Overwatch 2 crossover skin concept has been identified below:

Aang Zenyatta

If there was any character that suited an Aang-themed cosmetic, it's definitely Zenyatta. After all, this guy literally floats around with his feet tucked up, just like the pose Aang uses when he sits on his Air Scooter. On top of that, Zenyatta is a very peaceful monk with a calm, tranquil personality and tone, much like the older monks who lived on the Air Temple Islands where Aang grew up. It goes without saying that this is definitely one of the best recent Zenyatta cosmetics, especially on the chance that his bundle may include an Air Scooter emote.

Appa Orisa

Would Aang even be Aang without his big fluffy Sky Bison buddy, Appa, by his side? Thankfully, Appa also made an appearance in Overwatch 2 x Avatar: The Last Airbender crossover event with a cosmetic for none other than Omnic Tank, Orisa. The cosmetic does seem to suit Orisa rather well, much like many of the other animal and creature-inspired skins she has received over the years. It will be interesting to see what kind of emotes or highlight intro may come with this one in particular though, as Appa primarily soars through the sky.

Katara Mei

Mei is pretty much the perfect character to receive a Katara cosmetic, already wearing blue colored clothing, and having snow/ice powers, similar to Katara's Water Bending - which can also be used to send out water bullets/darts, water splash/spray, and water walls, much like many of Mei's abilities. Mei definitely suits and combines well with the influences from Katara's outfit, hairstyle, and Southern Water Tribe garments, so any other bonus items or highlight intro for this one could only make it better.

Toph Venture

Finally, after months and months of not receiving any new content, Venture is to receive their second-ever hero skin, giving an additional option for this hero other than the defaults or their Ice Cream-themed skin. This time, they'll be portraying Toph, which works rather well considering Venture's ability to burrow underground, and Toph being an Earth Bender who learned Earthbending from the Badgermoles, who tunnel underground.

Suki Kiriko

If there was a character who Kiriko would suit for a skin (other than Mai), then Suki is about as close as it gets. While Mai uses weaponry, Suki is more involved across each ark and is a member of the Gaang, just like every other character found in these crossover skins. As Suki is a Kiyoshi Warrior who utilizes melee tools and weaponry such as fans and a katana rather than a bending style, she suits Kiriko and her use of Kunai relatively well. Plus, both have extensive training in their martial arts with Kiriko's upbringing and training from her mother and Suki's dedication to the Kiyoshi Warriors.

Zuko Genji

Last but certainly not least, there's Genji taking on a cosmetic for Prince Zuko. Much like the others, these characters share quite a few similarities, both having troubled pasts with a transition to a more peace-oriented, good-aligned role in their society or organization. On top of this, both Zuko and Genji wield swords, so it would be a nice addition to see Genji's Dragonblade, usually Green, take on a fiery orange or red glow to reference Zuko's Firebending.
